newsitem.title: USA: PRESS DIGEST - Wall Street Journal - April 1.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Wall Street Journal - April 1.

text.p: The following stories were reported in Tuesday's electronic version of The Wall Street Journal:
* The Dow Jones industrials fell 157.11 points to 6,583.48, after falling 140 points on Thursday.
* The Supreme Court upheld a federal law requiring cable companies to carry local broadcast signals.
* Ascend Communications's shares fell although the company's proposed purchase of Cascade Communications was seen preparing the company for competition with Cisco .
* Trading in Bre-X Minerals shares is expected to resume Tuesday although the company asked for a trading halt during an independent verification of its Indonesia gold property.
* Personal income rose 0.9 percent in February and personal spending rose 0.3 percent.
* Strong corn and soybean prices and a livestock market recovery should help the financial position of farmers as the spring planting season starts.
* California regulators approved SBC Communications plan to acquire PacTel.
* An attempt by Columbia/HCA to get doctors to invest in a Florida hospital revealed some of the company's controversial financial agreements.
* Equifax said its Insurance Information Services unit agreed to buy Kroll Associates.
* In the first quarter, stock and bond underwriting rose 12 percent to $273.3 billion while initial public offerings fell 28 percent to $5.9 billion.
* A former Avis employee told a New York State assembly hearing counter agents at Avis's La Guardia Airport facility were told by managers not to rent cars to certain black customers.
* ITT sold its remaining stake in French telecommunications equipment maker Alcatel Alsthom for $530 million.
* Hokkaido Takushoku Bank and Hokkaido Bank announced a merger plan valued at $1.14 billion.
* General Electric said it would consolidate stakes in cable networks owned by Cablevision's Rainbow Programming into a 25 percent equity stake in the unit.

* Heard on the Street: Now people are starting to worry. A second straight session of sharp selling at the end of the trading day has left many investors chewing their fingernails and wondering whether it is time to look for a way out.
* Credit markets: A second straight big decline in stocks jostled the bond market but with different effects on short and long maturities.
